note.note: i.e. marvellous to me is the grace of God that ye have.

note.gloss: .i. per praedicationem .i. amal ropridchad dúib cotdóith si
note.note: i.e. as hath been preached unto you preserve it.
i.e. it is all with you.

note.gloss: .i. rofitid primum aduentum per euangelium, rofessid secundum aduentum per reuelationem
note.note: i.e. ye know primum aduentum, etc., ye will know secundum, etc.

note.gloss: .i. inóentid coirp crist ut sitis fili Dei et uós
note.note: i.e. in unity of Christ’s Body, ut, etc.

note.gloss: dobeirsom ainm bráthre doib arnaepret isara miscuis incúrsachad act isaraseircc
note.note: He gives (the) name of ‘brothers’ to them lest they should say the reproving is out of hatred of them, but it is out of love of them.

note.gloss: .i. ut unam fidem habeatis hisunt tra ↄricc frissalind serb inchúrsactha lase foruillecta beóil inchalich dimil cosse anall .i. uerba lenia et amicalia rurádi friu
note.note: Herein, then, he comes into contact with the bitter drink of the reproval, when the lips of the chalice have hitherto been smeared with honey, that is, uerba lenia et amicalia which he had spoken to them.

note.gloss: .i. ↄrop inonn cretem bes hifar cridiu et anasberaid hó bélib [over v. 11] doadbadar sund tra causa pro qua scripta est æpistola .i. irbága robatar leosom eter desciplu et debe óentu immurgu eter amagistru mógisidi uili do dia act dorigénsat indescipuil dechor etarru etdeu diib ished on ↄsecha som hic
note.note: i.e. so that the belief which is in your heart, and what ye utter with (your) lips may be the same. Here, then, is shown causa, etc., i.e. they had had contentions and discord among the disciples; unity, however, among their masters. They are all servants of God; but the disciples had made a distinction between them and (made) gods of them: that is what he (Paul) corrects híc.
i.e. another thing has been signified(?) to me.
i.e. they are not worldly contentions.
i.e. these are the contentions that are among you.

note.gloss: Pelagius: diuiditur corpus ubi membra desensiunt .i. airmitiu féid inchinn dothabirt donaib ballaib
note.note: i.e. in giving to the members the respect due to the head.
i.e. it is on myself I will touch at first.

note.gloss: cepudono adrad dǽ dothabirt dopool inchruthsin
note.note: why, then, was the worship due to God to be given to Paul in that wise?

note.gloss: .i. qui sé non dicunt in nomine meo babtizatos .i. nihed for nindassi insin
note.note: i.e. that is not your manner.
i.e. if I baptize you.
besides this.

note.gloss: .i. ní cuman lim marud baitsius nachnaile
note.note: i.e. I remember not if I have baptized any other.

note.gloss: .i. ut dixit ut portas nomen nostrum coram gentibus precept dosom didiu ettodiuschud combad aurlam cách diabathis et a descipul som donbathis iarom arnach naurchoissed som friníi duronad nachaile
note.note: that he should preach then and arouse, so that every one should be ready for his baptism, and that his (Paul’s) disciple should perform the baptism afterwards, so that he might not be hindered at (i.e. by doing) anything which any other could do.

note.gloss: .i. in qua uos gloriamini .i. nipu nachderninnse ǽm act nítuccfither rún inna cruche mad sulbair et mad án inprecept, crúx didu ainm dogním inchrochtho acht tremiberar disuidiu ↄidainm dunchrunn
note.note: i.e. not that I could not have done it indeed, but the mystery of the Cross will not be understood if the preaching be eloquent and brilliant. Crux, then, (is) a name for the act of crucifixion, but it is transferred from that, so that it is a name for the tree.

note.gloss: .i. ní date leu incoimdiu dochrochad et isburbe
note.note: i.e. it is not agreeable to them that the Lord was crucified, and it is foolishness.

note.gloss: .i. apparebit gentilis de grecís .i. bid cuingid rochuingid argebaid inscol foraréli
note.note: i.e. apparebit gentilis de Graecis? i.e. it will be a great question, for one school will attack the other.
i.e. it is manifest quod, etc.
i.e. it is therefore I say to thee stultam.

note.gloss: .i. elimentís ɫ. iccach æcnu as æcne dodia
note.note: in every wisdom that is wisdom unto God
they understood it not per, etc.

note.gloss: .i. nítorbe lasuidiu precept doib manidénatar ferte occa
note.note: i.e. they deem preaching to them no profit unless miracles be wrought thereat.
i.e. they deem it no profit unless it be eloquent.

note.gloss: .i. praedicamus .i. ní mebol limsa isstultitia leusom ón et isscandalum
note.note: i.e. I deem it no shame: they deem it stultitia and scandalum.

note.gloss: .i. aní nad comnactar dóini trianecne cotánic som triachroich .i. aní ↄoitechtatar iudei et greci .i. uirtutem et sapientiam fagebtis sí credidisent amal donducet uocati rl.
note.note: i.e. that which men could not do by their wisdom, He could do it by His cross, i.e. that which Iudaei et Graeci have sought, i.e. uirtutem et sapientiam, they would have found it si credidissent, as uocati, etc., understand it.
i.e. O all (ye) faithful!
i.e. he will not be sapiens if it be secundum carnem.

note.gloss: .i. uocati sunt .i. nitat æcni huili .i. ni sochude diib ataat and [in marg. l.] ɫ. ní sochude as potens mad secundum carnem arishé assapiens et aspotens et asfortis et asnobilis qui credit in iesum christum et quod docet ipse
note.note: i.e. all are not wise, that is, it is not a multitude of them; there are some, however. Or it is not a multitude that is potens if it be secundum carnem, for it is he who is sapiens, and who is potens, and who is fortis, and who is nobilis, qui credit, etc.

note.gloss: .i. elegit .i. indí nád ní libsi in sapientia homana
note.note: i.e. that which ye deem nothing in, etc.
not from any other.

note.gloss: asé [in marg.] in heremia uel in libro hoc
.i. comadas lobre et immomon forsin mug céin ṁbíis ocfognam diachoimdid
note.note: i.e. meet (is) weakness and great fear on the slave so long as he is serving his master.

note.gloss: .i. níp and nob irpaid .i. in philosophia
note.note: i.e. not therein shall ye trust, i.e. in philosophia.

note.gloss: Pelagius: cum sapientia sua per nostrum euangelium ɫ. eterscértar acoirp etananmin friu ɫ. eterscérthar anecne friu
note.note: their bodies and their souls will be separated from them, or their wisdom will be separated from them.

note.gloss: Pelagius: ab incredulís .i. conafitir nech diæcnib indomuin
note.note: i.e. so that none of the wise men of the world knoweth.
i.e. what are they which He has prepared?
i.e. a similitude this.
i.e. save the man himself.
i.e. homine who considers it.

note.gloss: .i. isinchrud sin rofitir intí imbíi inspirut nóib rúna dée
note.note: i.e. it is thus that he in whom is the Holy Spirit knoweth God’s mysteries.
i.e. faithful ones.
i.e. we preach.
i.e. when we provide (comparamus), i.e. his suitable teaching to each.
i.e. like unto a beast.
i.e. not proper to this is a spirituale documentum.

note.gloss: .i. dimeccither alled frispirut .i. a deo uel a spiritali homine
note.note: i.e. he is reprobated as regards the spirit.
i.e. no one sets reprobation upon him.

note.gloss: .i. ishé sensus forchain etargne domini dochách
note.note: i.e. that is the sensus, which teaches knowledge Domini to every one.

note.gloss: .i. hominibus perfectís in fide .i. niforcital óisa foirbthi forchanim dúib arnifulngidsi ón
note.note: i.e. not the teaching of perfect folk do I teach unto you, for ye endure not that.

note.gloss: .i. gluass for accarnalibus .i. nitad foirbthi forṅ gnímai hicrist
note.note: i.e. a gloss on the ‘carnalibus,’ that is, your deeds in Christ are not perfect.
i.e. it is not strong teaching.
i.e. therefore it is not food that I have given you.
i.e. for ye are not better than at first.
i.e. the carnal desire still weighs you down.
i.e. it is this that makes carnal men of you.
i.e. these are ‘contentiones et emulationes.’

note.gloss: .i. cindas fer diandenid si deu .i. mogæ et timthirthidi indí diaruchretsidsi
note.note: i.e. of what sort of men do ye make gods? i.e. slaves and servants of Him in whom ye have believed.
i.e. as they have been entrusted to him.
i.e. is not to be counted as anything.
i.e. it is He that is somewhat.
i.e. it is well-known, they are labourers.

note.gloss: Pelagius: non secundum meam uirtutem .i. is per gratiam cotofutaincsi dano
note.note: i.e. it is per gratiam that he upbuilds you then.

note.gloss: [in marg. l.] .i. intí diarupridchad superedificat .i. ni limsa (supere)dificare sed fundamentum ponere
note.note: i.e. he to whom it has been preached superaedificat: it is not mine superaedificare, sed, etc.
i.e. it is proper to build to the foundation.
i.e. though false apostles should attempt it.
i.e. both good and evil.
i.e. if he be steadfast in tribulations, and if his work be good.
i.e. he that builds up minor sins.

note.gloss: .i. díith .i. mercedis dum non bene custodit gregem. [in marg.] dernum
note.note: i.e. loss ....

note.gloss: .i. besslán .i. solus euadet separatus a grege suo
note.note: i.e. who will be saved.
i.e. are ye ignorant?
i.e. it were not proper to pollute it.
i.e. ye are that temple.
i.e. let him become, that is, let him make himself stupid.

note.gloss: .i. isdiliu dó intí lasmbi æcne .i. ladia
note.note: i.e. dearer to him is He in whose opinion he is wise, that is, in God’s.
i.e. not usual is good through it.

note.gloss: .i. ingeb sa ut non sint sapientes
note.note: i.e. I will reproach ut, etc.
in craftiness, that is, in cunning or in cleverness.

note.gloss: Pelagius: nos uestri sumus ministri uos autem pleps solius christi ithé omnia inso asmbeirsom sís
note.note: these are the omnia which he mentions below.

note.gloss: .i. predicta .i. cedono rigne occo itlib huili
note.note: i.e. what, then, is the good of prolixity in it? they all are yours.
i.e. that is the same as ‘uita.’
i.e. that is the same as ‘mors.’
i.e. let this be the judgment that is passed upon us.
i.e. we set forth the divine mysteries.

note.gloss: .i. ishé didiu intecttaire maith condaig indocbáil diathigerni et non sibi ipsi .i. is hed insin ↄdegar and
note.note: i.e. he, then, is the good messenger who seeks glory for his lord et non sibi ipsi, i.e. that is what is sought in him.

note.gloss: .i. isbeic lim inbrígsin cedmolad cedtatháir dom beraidsi domsa isbeicc limsa abríg
note.note: i.e. little do I care: though it be praise, though it be blame that ye give me, little do I care.

note.gloss: .i. samaltir inmolad dóinde frilaithe aragairti ṁbís ut profeta dicit diem hominum non concupiui id est laudem eorum
note.note: i.e. human praise is likened to a day because of the short time that it abides.

note.gloss: .i. iudicat mé in bono ɫ. in malo dominus est .i. ishé dia aseola indium sa
note.note: i.e. it is God who is knowing in me.
i.e. I am not righteous as to it.
i.e. until the true Judge shall come.

note.gloss: .i. comalnid annupridchim niepur brithemnact fornech naform féin quasi [in marg.] dixisset isairi trimirothorṅdiussa indium inna huilisa asrubartmar ánáll .i. arcor hifarselbadsi et epert ammi mogæ dúibsi et arnebmóidem himagistrib ut gamalial rl. et nebmes for nech ↄdid messed in coimdiu ↄsechide humaldóit huáimse .i. fornebmóidem himagistru et nebmess fornech immaid fa olcc ↄdidmessed dia
.i. cani tú féin .i. ad inflatos dicit
note.note: i.e. is it not thou thyself?

note.gloss: .i. ciarfemtha so iudicium quasi a té ipso susciperis nipo móiti cenmánom accipisti
note.note: i.e. though thou shouldst receive iudicium, etc., it were nothing to boast of : besides accepisti.
i.e. not under our yoke are ye.

note.gloss: .i. amal nombemmis érchóilti .i. fo béesad fir téte dochath argaibidside céil forbáas intain téte donchath
note.note: i.e. as though we were destined, that is, after the manner of a man who goes to battle, for he expects death when he goes to the battle.
i.e. a multitude’s eye beholds us.

note.gloss: .i. precept dosom fridei etsaithar ho lámaib in nocte
note.note: i.e. to him (there is) teaching by day and labour with hands in nocte.
i.e it is (the) fruit of his hands that used to support him.

note.gloss: .i. amal bimmis octarche .i. quod enim iecitur foras purgatur síc apostoli ab hominibus ieciuntur
note.note: as if we were dregs.

note.gloss: .i. escart ɫ. perditio: Pelagius: peripsima graecum est et pessimi interpretatur ɫ. dispecti

note.note: i.e. until this, i.e. until the time in which we are.
i.e. a perfect (number) for an imperfect.

note.gloss: .i. innacoschométide .i. puer[or]um custodes .i. óis foirbthe bíte ocbaithius [in marg.] podos graecum pés latinum, gogos graecum tectum latinum .i. costigthith qui secitur doctorem ɫ. custos pedum interpretatur
note.note: i.e. of the foot-protectors, i.e. puerorum custodes, that is the perfect folk who are at baptism ....
i.e. though your teachers be abundant.

note.gloss: .i. istoich dom farṅguide hóre adimmaicc mihi et amathirse uobís
note.note: i.e. it is a natural right for me to ask you, for ye are sons mihi, and I am a father uobis.

note.gloss: .i. bedadthramli .i. gaibid comarbus for nathar et intamlid abéssu
note.note: i.e. be ye father-like, that is, take your father’s succession and imitate his manners.
i.e. he imitates my manners.
i.e. who shall teach you.
i.e. he shall declare to you what are my manners.
i.e. it is in Christ those ways are.

note.gloss: .i. amal nirisinse do barcoscsi riccubsa ǽm
note.note: i.e. as though I were not coming to correct you. I will come indeed.

note.gloss: Pelagius: ut de aduentu terreret eos .i. doimmarr anúail diarrísa
note.note: i.e. I will restrain their pride if I come.
i.e. I shall know how ye are.
i.e. bonum opus, this is what I shall praise.

note.gloss: .i. is lib atá arogu tra mad ferr cotob sechfider dichosscc alailiu aithirgid bésu diandaithirsid ón isindeseircc etspirut rigthir cuccuib
note.note: i.e. it is you, then, that have the choice: if it be better ye will be corrected by another correction. Emend (your) manners: if ye emend them, it is in love and in a spirit (of meekness) that one will go to you.
i.e. that were meeter quam inflatio.

note.gloss: .i. conibé eter in peccato act cobeid in pænitentia
note.note: i.e. so that he may not be at all in peccato but that he may be in poenitentia.
i.e. he is present, then, when his word is read out.
i.e. as I am present.
i.e. not in my own authority have I judged him.

note.gloss: .i. in earum literarum iudicio ɫ. isónspirut rouiccius brith
note.note: i.e. it is from the Spirit I have passed judgment.

note.gloss: [in marg. ad v. 4] iudicaui ǽm tradere dondnindinsinse ɫ. dodnindnastise uós. Aliter isdo dásact asberar athindnaculsa istresodin bidslán á animsom in die domini rl.
note.note: iudicaui indeed tradere, that I should deliver him; or that ye should deliver him. Aliter, to madness it is said that he is given up: through this will his soul be saved in die Domini, etc.

note.gloss: satane .i. donfresndid .i. pænitentiæ .i. iscotarsne dondúalig insualig darahési
note.note: Satanae, i.e. to the adversary, i.e. poenitentiae, i.e. opposed to the vice is the virtue which takes its place.
i.e. that his soul may be saved.
i.e. that ye could not pass judgment on this crime.
i.e. a lump of dough.
i.e. unsoured, that is, without sourness of sin.

note.gloss: .i. amal arrograd descad fobairgin isollumun agni síc nicoir descad pectho do buith isollummun agni .i. christi
note.note: i.e. as leaven in bread had been forbidden at the solemnity agni, sic it is not proper for the leaven of sin to be at the solemnity Agni, i.e. Christi.
i.e. at Christ’s feast.
uselessness.

note.gloss: .i. díuitte linn et fírinne ut fuit adam rénimmarmus
note.note: i.e. simplicity with us and righteousness, ut fuit Adam before sinning.

note.gloss: [in marg.] non utique fornicariis .i. isirdurcu epirt lim són airrofetar ní biedsi hicobodlus lasuidiu alioquín debueratis arnitaat cosmuli ambésasa fribsi ished astécte dúib nébeth immalle
note.note: i.e. I need not say (non utique), for I know that ye will not be in communion with them, alioquin debueratis, for their customs are not like unto you. This is right for you, not to be along (with them).

note.gloss: .i. isairi scripsi. Pelagius: melius nobís fuerat de hác luce migrare quam indigne per commonionem gentium consortio separari
note.note: i.e. it is therefore scripsi.

note.gloss: .i. ni hedón scripsi uobís .i. non commiscemini .i. ni epur frib etarscarad frisuidiu .i. frigenti fobíith precepte dóib duús induccatar fo hiris alioquín .i. armain bed accuiss napreceptesin debueritis nótresstæ dithír ettalam nání sin cotobárrig tra ort precepte ↄnachdigtith
.i. infectsa .i. ní aidrech limm quod scripsi atbiur beos
note.note: i.e. this time, that is, I regret not quod scripsi: I say it still.
i.e. a reviler or condemner.
it is so.
i.e. eating with him in a house, or receiving his food.
i.e. what profits? i.e. it profits nothing.
i.e. it is frater that I say quid enim, etc.

note.gloss: [in marg.] beim foris lemm (in)so forsaní asrubart riam ɫ. istitul dondí dodiármo(rat)
note.note: This seems to me a recapitulation of what he had said before; or it is a title to that which follows it.
i.e. they have a judge without you, even Christ.
i.e. dares: i.e. there is another evil among you.
i.e. a suit or a judgment.
a judgment.
i.e. that he be judged.
i.e. it is not churchfolk who are judges among you.
i.e. if ye had known, ye would not snatch the petty judgments from them.

note.gloss: Pelagius: per uós siue uestro exemplo .i. bid ibarcumactusi miastir indomunso
note.note: i.e. it will be in your power that this world will be judged.

note.gloss: [in marg.] iudicabimus .i. hireschaib angelos .i. demones .i. fobíith ba deidbiriu dúnni immormus assinfolud appriscc inna colno araróitmar ceimroimsimmis ol ṁ bói dosom asinfolud tanidiu araróit isairi dano messimmirni forrusom rl. ɫ. messimmir innafíraingliu .i. ishé cruth inso ǽm nosmessammar .i. amal bete som inimpudiu inna brithemnacte bemmini dano ut dicit uocabit caelum desusum et terram discernere populum suum ɫ. de crísto dicitur qui in nostra homana natura angelos iudicabit ɫ. sancti excelsiores iudicabunt inferiores
adláig bite oc pennit in æclesiís
note.note: ex-laymen who are at penance in ecclesiis.
i.e. let it be them who give judgments among you.
i.e. unto your shame.

note.gloss: .i. isnaddixnigedar nach æcne hóre isamne dognither
note.note: i.e. it is that there is no wise man, seeing that it is thus done.
i.e. it is this, however, which ye do.

note.gloss: .i. nípu libsi intórdso act ba laamiresschu
note.note: i.e. this practice should not be yours, but should be left to unbelievers.
i.e. even assuredly.

note.gloss: .i. issí in so intargabáal ishé inpeccath forarele .i. fornicatio prius et iudicia [in marg. l.] qui semper habere pacem debueratis etiam cum detrimento rerum temporalium
note.note: i.e. this is the trespass; this is the sin upon another.

note.gloss: .i. cid atobaich cendílgud cech ancridi dognethe frib et níbethe fria acre
note.note: i.e. what impels you not to forgive every injury that may have been done to you, and that ye should not be complaining of it?
i.e. it were better than to avenge it.

note.gloss: .i. ní dilgaid anancride dogníther frib act atgairith
note.note: i.e. ye forgive not the injury that is done you, but ye complain of it.
i.e. ye take away from every one, and ye defraud every one.

note.gloss: [in marg.] .i. opus .i. nibu chumme dúib ce bad hé frisandénte
note.note: i.e. it were not the same for you that ye should do it to him.

note.gloss: .i. ithé inimici lessom qui fraudant et qui iniuriam faciunt
note.note: i.e. these he deems inimici qui, etc.

note.gloss: adultor est qui ultra terminum statum matrimonii graditur

note.note: i.e. the sodomites.

note.gloss: .i. qui aliis maledicunt .i. áis bíis ocirchollud
note.note: i.e. folk who are reviling.

note.gloss: .i. asenud uille tra nibiat inóentu muintire nime
note.note: i.e. the whole synod of them, then, will not be in the unity of heaven’s household.

note.gloss: .i. nomina ɫ. opera ropo ainm dúibsi tra inso uile ɫ. darigensi inso uile
note.note: all this, then, has been a name of yours: or ye have done all this.

note.gloss: .i. inglaine sin et indnóibe etinfírinne isinanmim inchoimded ísu crist et inspiruto nóib dúibsi atrédesin [in marg.] taidmenadar sund tra nateora persana .i. pater et filius et spiritus sanctus
note.note: i.e. that purity and the holiness and the righteousness in the name of the Lord Jesus Christ and of the Holy Ghost, unto you (are) those three things. Here, then, he recalls the three Persons (of the Trinity), i.e. Pater, etc.

note.gloss: .i. nimtharberar fochumactu nach sásta diib ut ebriosi redigantur a uino et similia
note.note: i.e. I am not brought under the power of any food of them, ut ebriosi, etc.
i.e. near is their kinship.
i.e. escam: but it is the man that worships those two things.
i.e. it will be clear to them.

note.gloss: .i. dubrú ... assom tra híc aratairchela natúari .i. doirgairiu étrith arminibed cróis nibíad étrad
note.note: i.e. to the belly ... that he may restrict the viands, that is, to forbid lust, for if gluttony were not, lust would not exist.

note.gloss: .i. ↄdid flaith do incoimdiu is bésad inna flatho doem et dofich
note.note: i.e. so that the Lord is a prince to it: it is the usage of the prince that he protects and he punishes.

note.gloss: .i. quia membra eius sumus .i. incorp imbaflaith in coimdiu dodíusgibther side, trinert innadeacte amal dorodiusgud arcoimdiu ísu
note.note: i.e. the body wherein the Lord shall be prince, it will be roused through the might of the Godhead, even as our Lord Jesus has been roused.

note.gloss: .i. ingét abullu arcrist etindigén bullu mertrige diib absit
note.note: i.e. shall I snatch His members from Christ, and shall I make of them a harlot’s members? absit!

note.gloss: .i. ardoecmalla inmertrech cuicce pecthu indlína dodaaidlea combi óinchorp pectho asṁberar et asberar corp dondlúim máirsin innapecthach intí immurgu téte adochumsi doecmallaside foir indlúim máir inchoirpsin etinphecthasin bís forsin mertrich et nísṅderigsi dano act atballat diblínaib
note.note: i.e. for the harlot gathers unto her the sins of those that visit her, so that it is said to be one body of sin, and that great mass of sinners is called ‘body.’ Now he that goes to her gathers on him the great mass of that body and of that sin which is on the harlot, and it does not leave her, but they both perish.
i.e. shun ye and let it be quickly, for it is proper to shun it.
i.e. except lust.

note.gloss: .i. imfolngi corp dossom .i. corp innapecthe bíte for sinmertrich
note.note: i.e. he makes to him a body, that is, the body of the sins which are on the harlot.

note.gloss: .i. isglé limm niↄdigénte étrad marufeste inso
note.note: i.e. it is clear to me that ye would not commit fornication if ye knew this.
i.e. from the Godhead.
i.e. ye are not your own.
let Him be your burden.

note.gloss: .i. ba uissiu dúib oldáte pecthe dobuid and
note.note: i.e. it were more proper for you than for sins to be therein.

note.gloss: .i. questionibus arrufoitea epistli uaidib som conaidchomarcaib cucisom
note.note: for letters had been sent from them with questions to him.
i.e. this is the answer which ye take from me.

note.gloss: .i. ni cumuing imfogbaidetith nalanamnas maniptol lasinfer
note.note: i.e. she cannot practise continence or copulate unless the husband pleases.
i.e. unless it be agreeable to the husband.

note.gloss: .i. nach moided dano infer infectso hicumactu arnicumuingside dano imfogbaidetid nálanamnas maniptol apud mulierem
note.note: i.e. let then the husband not boast this time in (his) power, for he, too, cannot practise continence or copulate unless mulier pleases.
to defraud yourselves.

note.gloss: .i. na tiubrad cách achéle .i. ex ratione coniugii
note.note: i.e. let not each defraud the other.
i.e. save only.
i.e. except ye be at one as to it.

note.gloss: .i. in quadragensimis et in temporibus partús et menstrualis doloris
.i. arna dich cách assadligud inadaltras trilathar demuin et tribarnebcongabthetitsi
note.note: i.e. lest every one go out of his duty into adultery through the Devil’s influence and through your incontinence.

note.gloss: .i. mad moríarsa dognethe and issamlid inso nobiad chách amal rongabusa .i. inógi híc ostenditur uirginitás
note.note: i.e. if it were my will that ye did therein, it is thus that every one would be, as I am, that is, in celibacy hic, etc.
i.e. both celibacy and matrimony.

note.gloss: .i. etsi uolo bés nibatchutrummi huili act cinibetsom samlumsa inógi bith ítuil dée biet huili
note.note: i.e. etsi uolo, peradventure all may not be equal; but though they be not like me in celibacy, it will be in God’s will that they all will be, [that is, whether in celibacy or matrimony].

note.gloss: Pelagius: incipit alia causa de uiduís .i. bíte iṅgenas
note.note: i.e. who are in chastity.

note.gloss: Hieronymus: ideo melius nubere quam peius úri olcc asferr ulcc inso
note.note: an evil that is better than an evil, this.
i.e. it is this that I enjoin.

note.gloss: .i. ma eterróscra friafer nítéit cofer ṅaile act bed ingenas
note.note: i.e. if she should separate from her husband, she goes not to another husband, but shall be in chastity.

note.gloss: .i. madcotecht di cofer bad hé afer incétne
note.note: i.e. if it (comes) to her going to a husband, let the first one be her husband.

note.gloss: .i. ni liim for suide is dominus immurgu dicit uxorem a uiro non descedere
note.note: i.e. I do not make Him responsible. It is Dominus, however, (who) dicit, etc.
i.e. he likes her companionship.

note.gloss: .i. na scarad frisinfer dús inríctar triagnáissi
note.note: i.e. let her not part from the husband, if perchance he may be saved through her companionship.

note.gloss: .i. teccomnocuir inso is airi didiu asbiursa ambuith immallei dús inríctar indalanái trialaile
note.note: i.e. this has happened. Therefore, then, I say that they should be together if perchance one of the twain be saved through the other.

note.gloss: [in marg.] alioquin .i. mainip inchrudso bid anglan for cland .i. alliles dind ancretmiuch bid ancretmech
note.note: i.e. unless it be in this wise, your children will be unclean, that is, what shall cleave to the unbelieving will be unbelieving.

note.gloss: .i. filii hore ataaithsi immelei et adibcretmich in fectsa cretmech dano forcland
note.note: because ye are together and are now believing, your children also (will be) believing.

note.gloss: .i. nach nastad incretmech et na coméitged dó
note.note: i.e. let not the believer detain him, and let him (the believer) not be indulgent to him.
i.e. let us not have strife with any one.
i.e. thou wilt save the man though thou keep him with thee perforce.

note.gloss: .i. áfir can rofestasu íccfe inmnái ciatasode lat arécin
note.note: i.e. O man, whence shouldst thou know that thou wilt save the woman though thou keep her with thee perforce?

note.gloss: .i. amal fondrodil incoimdiu dochách siue cum coiuge ɫ. in uirginitate
note.note: i.e. as the Lord hath distributed it to every one.

note.gloss: .i. imbinógi imbilánamnas amal dorograd bíd samlid [in marg.] ishé inso titul indligid archinn ciasberthar combad béim foris indligid remeperthi
note.note: i.e. whether in celibacy or in marriage, as he hath been called, let him be so. This is the title of the dictum that follows, though it is said that it is a recapitulation of the dictum aforesaid.
i.e. that is what I teach to every one.

note.gloss: .i. uirginitas .i. imdibthe ólanamnas ar ni dond imdibu colnidiu lessom inso ut uirginitas circumcidit uitia
note.note: i.e. circumcised from marriage; for he is not here speaking of the fleshly circumcision.

note.gloss: .i. na téit illánamnas issuáichnid híc náich doimdibu colnidu ání thúas ɫ. nacuinged amenme praeputium mad imdibthe
note.note: i.e. let him not enter matrimony: it is obvious híc that what is above is not of the fleshly circumcision: or let not his mind seek praeputium if it be circumcised.

note.gloss: .i. non demittat uxorem ɫ. naepred amenme armbad ferr són
note.note: let not his mind say that that would be better.

note.gloss: .i. ni lour deit buid censétchi mani déne dagnímu
note.note: i.e. it is not enough for thee to be without a wife, unless thou do good works.

note.gloss: .i. sechib grád imbether and impóge falánamnas istaschide timne dée dochomalnad and
note.note: i.e. whatsoever the condition in which one is, whether it be celibacy or matrimony, it is necessary to fulfil God’s commandments therein.
i.e. without any changing.
i.e. seek not celibacy.

note.gloss: .i. cechoníis cor dosétche uáit níiscoirther act indnite dús imcomchétbuid dúib
note.note: i.e. though thou may be able to put thy wife away from thee, thou shalt not put her away; but wait to see if ye can agree.

note.gloss: .i. is illánamnas dorograd dochum ṅ dée
note.note: i.e. it is in matrimony he has been called unto God.

note.gloss: .i. sóirmug .i. issóirchele dodia nido tantum seruit
note.note: i.e. a free-slave, that is, he is a freedman unto God, not Him tantum seruit.
i.e. without half service coniugio.

note.gloss: .i. bíth and beos act ropo ituil dée
note.note: i.e. let him still abide therein provided it be in God’s will.

note.gloss: .i. níhed asrúbart side bíth nech inógi cidsochumact nodochumact do ceist cid asrubart incoimdiu nianse qui potest capere capiat
note.note: i.e. this is not what He had said, let any one abide in celibacy whether he be well-able or ill-able thereto. Question, what hath the Lord said? Easy (to answer): qui potest, etc.

note.gloss: .i. ar mad forṅgaire dognein docoischifed pían athairmthecht
note.note: i.e. for if it were a command that I gave, punishment would follow transgression thereof.
i.e. as I am trustworthy at the mission to which I have come.

note.gloss: .i. massu cut séitchi rocretis na scarad frit iarcretim
note.note: i.e. if thou hast believed with thy wife, let her not part from thee after believing.

note.gloss: .i. manid coséitchi rocretis natuic séitchi iarcretim
note.note: i.e. if thou hast not believed with a wife, take not a wife after believing.

note.gloss: .i. nígatda diib cammaif imnetha inbetho .i. breth et altram et anasansam diib díth fochricce
note.note: i.e. the troubles of the world, however, it takes not from them, to wit, bearing children and nursing, and what is hardest of them, loss of reward.
i.e. that you should be in celibacy.

note.gloss: .i. isdered ṁbetho inso nifíu sercc do thabairt do [in left marg.] ɫ. isfurgrad inso ut qui habent .i. ished inso arathá ut qui rl.
note.note: i.e. this is the end of the world, it is not worth while to love it: or this is what remaineth over, ut, etc., i.e. this is what awaiteth, ut, etc.

note.gloss: .i. amal ṁbís ingen et athir siur et brathir
note.note: i.e. as is daughter and father, sister and brother.

note.gloss: .i. amal nístectitis ɫ. co beit amal innahí nadtectat sétchi
note.note: i.e. as if they had them not, or that they may be as those that have not wives.

note.gloss: .i. amal nahí nádchiat ɫ. amal nícetis
note.note: i.e. as those that weep not, or as if they wept not.
i.e. like those that buy not.
i.e. as if they used not.

note.gloss: .i. nibí nach dethiden foir act fognam dodia noch ba hedón bachóir
note.note: i.e. there is no care upon him save service unto God, but that were proper.

note.gloss: .i. ní dethiden dosuidiu act fognam uxori
note.note: i.e. his only care is to serve uxori.

note.gloss: .i. issain ordo dogní cechtar nái .i. mulier et innubta
note.note: i.e. different is the ordo which each of them makes.
i.e. that is, the uirgo.
i.e. these things are what he mentions below.

note.gloss: Pelagius: non impono necessitatem inuitís .i. niarfarnastud inógi manip artháircud fochricce dúib
note.note: i.e. it is not to detain you in celibacy unless it be for the purpose of preparing a reward for you.

note.gloss: .i. ished didiu anhonestum guide dée cen nachtairmescc ódethidin inbetho .i. ósétchi
note.note: i.e. this, then, is the honestum, to pray God without any interruption from the care of the world, that is, from a wife.
i.e. it is unseemly per, etc.
i.e. as the daughter desires it.
i.e. those two things (non habens necessitatem and potestatem habens suae uoluntatis) then, are carried through this text.

note.gloss: .i. asrochoili inna chridiu buid dondingin inógi ɫ. diacholin fondul toisech
note.note: i.e. he determines in his heart that the daughter should be in virginity, or in the first way (of explaining it) that his flesh shall.

note.gloss: tadbat som sund tra dechur fil eterlanamnas et ógi intain asṁberar non peccare coiugio et benefacere dondógi et intain asṁberar benefacere coiugio is melius facere uirginitatem
note.note: he manifests here the difference which there is between matrimony and virginity, when it is said non peccare coniugio (that wedlock sins not), it is likewise (said) that virginity benefacere, and when it is said benefacere coniugio (that wedlock doeth well), it is melius facere uirginitatem.
i.e. to (the) law of service to (the) husband.
i.e. so long as the husband is alive.

note.gloss: .i. baferr limm immurgu buith di inógi
note.note: i.e. I had rather, however, that she were in virginity.

note.gloss: .i. atá spirut dée indiumm baferr mochomairle dodénum
note.note: i.e. God’s spirit is in me: it were better that my counsel should be followed.

note.gloss: .i. nant ní ídol et nád nescona ní
note.note: i.e. that an idol is naught, and that it makes nothing unclean.

note.gloss: .i. afiussin immurgu bamaithsón act ní bed uall and atá són and tra et ní béo de
note.note: i.e. that knowledge, however, were good, provided there were no pride therein. That, now, is therein, and it (knowledge) is not alive therefrom.

note.gloss: .i. comaitecht don brathir enirt hiniriss conutuinc inniriss
note.note: i.e. indulgence to the weak brother in faith upbuilds the faith.

note.gloss: [in marg. inf.] .i. isamlid ba coir do fiuss inna nídol act ní arbarat biuth innatúari adopartar dondídol arná coscrad indeseircc ṁbráthardi trifrithorcuin donbráthir hiressach as énirt menme
note.note: i.e. it is thus that it were right for him to know the idols, provided they do not eat the meats that are offered to the idol, lest (this) should destroy the brotherly love through offence to the faithful brother who is weak of mind.
i.e. therein is he known to God, through indulgence to the feeble brother.

note.gloss: [in marg.] In conscientia .i. énirt acocubussom et is escon leu anadobarar do ídlaib act nosnerta insonirt doairbirt biuth inna túare sin et iscumme doib bid idalte domeltis hóre nitrisonirti nirisse damelat
note.note: i.e. feeble is their conscience, and they deem unclean what is offered to idols; but the firm (one) encourages them to eat those meats; and it is the same to them as though they ate an idol-offering, because it is not through firmness of faith that they consume it.
i.e. it is the same to them as though it were an idol-offering.

note.gloss: [in marg.] Offendiculum .i. is frithorcon leu athabairt forru ɫ. adénum fiadib
note.note: i.e. they deem it an offence to force them to it or to do it before them.
i.e. he eats what is on the altar of the idol.
i.e. conscientious.

note.gloss: [in marg.] .i. nertfidir nonné dicet manducabo idolathitum dum illud manducat qui est melior mé
note.note: i.e. it will be encouraged.

note.gloss: .i. babecc duitsiu cometecht dossom isairisom rocéss crist
note.note: i.e. it were little for you to be indulgent to him: it is for him that Christ hath suffered.

note.gloss: .i. hóre rombebe crist darcenn indóesa lobuir et itbóill docrist iarum intimmormus dognither friusom isfricrist dogníther
note.note: i.e. since Christ has died for sake of the feeble folk, and they, then, are members of Christ’s, the sin that is committed against them, is committed against Christ.

note.gloss: .i. is amal bid fri crist frisorthe
note.note: i.e. it is as though ye offended against Christ.

note.gloss: .i. hore isimmarmus hí crist anas olcc lasin brathir .i. maimfolṅgi díltud dunbráthir
note.note: i.e. because what seems evil to the brother is a sin in Christ, that is, if it causes scandal to the brother.
i.e. lest I should scandalize (him), i.e. lest scandal be caused to him.
is not?

note.gloss: .i. hore amabstal et amforcitlid dochách cainipsa sóir cedugnén cachṅgním
note.note: i.e. since I am an apostle and I am a teacher to every one, should I not be free though I did every deed?
i.e. good is my soul-friend.

note.gloss: .i. ó corinti .i. cani messe immoforling cretim dúibsi in domino
note.note: i.e. is it not I that have caused belief to you in Domino?

note.gloss: .i. indaapstal apho(pui)l décce lat corintiu et genti canirochretset isgním abstil ǽm immidforlingsón et is messe rophroidech doib
note.note: i.e. am I an apostle, O people? Look thou at (the) Corinthians and Gentiles; have not they believed? Truly it is an apostle’s work that has caused that, and it is I who have preached to them.

note.gloss: .i. batorad saithir dúun inchrudso cedumelmis cechtuari et cedugnemmis andugniat ar céli act ní bad nertad nambraithre et frescsiu fogchricce asmóo
note.note: i.e. it were a fruit of our labour in this wise, if we consumed every food and if we did what our fellows do; but it would not be a strengthening of the brethren and a hope of a greater reward.

note.gloss: .i. bete banscala occar timthirect nidunachoipred ailiu immurgu
note.note: i.e. that there should be females attending us; not, however, for any other operation.

note.gloss: .i. interrogatio .i. indoich bidsaindóire dúnni et barnaip
note.note: i.e is it likely that it should be a special slavery for me and Barnabas?

note.gloss: .i. atrede asrubart anúas amae attá linn potestas ar quis militat
note.note: i.e. the three things which he has mentioned above. Surely we have potestas, for quis militat (without his pay)?
i.e. it (feeding a flock) were a labour to him though he consume it (the milk).

note.gloss: .i. it dóindi tra haec exempla ɫ. non carnalia et non secundum hominem dico sed secundum spiritalem sensum .i. non per hominem sed per iesum christum
note.note: i.e. human then are haec exempla.
i.e. does it not say it? Nay, it saith it.

note.gloss: .i. dofuáircc .i. arisbés leosom indaim dothúarcuin indarbe
note.note: i.e. which treads out, i.e. for it is a custom among them (for) the oxen to tread out the corn.

note.gloss: .i. ba dochu són .i. is snisni ata bobes qui aramus terram cordium hominum
note.note: i.e. that were likelier, i.e. it is we who are boues qui, etc.

note.gloss: .i. quae dicit léx non alligabis rl. .i. ní dondaum storidiu actis dínni preceptorib aris díin asrobrad andedeso quoniam in spé rl.
note.note: i.e. it is not of the natural ox, but of us preachers; for it is of us these two things have been said, quoniam etc.
i.e. if we have preached.
i.e. is it much? that is, is it too much?

note.gloss: .i. ní dúibsi is sóibud spiritalia uainni dúibsi et carnalia uáibsi dúnni
note.note: i.e. it is not imposition to you: spiritualia (given) by us to you and carnalia by you to us.
i.e. were it not juster to give it to us?

note.gloss: .i. arná érbarthar isprecept arbiad nammá et arnadergaba línn cretmech et arṅ dom roibse fochricc
note.note: i.e. that it may not be said, it is teaching for food only, and that it may not diminish the multitude of believers, and that I may have a reward.

note.gloss: .i. cosmuilius aile lessom inso ba ṅdílmain dossom airbert biuth dithorud aprecepte
note.note: i.e. this (is) another simile which he has: to shew that he were free to eat of the fruit of his teaching.

note.gloss: .i. locc imbítis primsacairt ocirnigdi .i. inter sancta sanctorum
note.note: i.e. a place wherein the chief-priests used to be a-praying.

note.gloss: .i. dlíged sacairt itempul is doib doberthe
note.note: i.e. a priest’s right in the temple, it is to them it used to be given.

note.gloss: .i. ithé són leuiti olchene nobítis octimthirecht innanidbart
note.note: i.e. those are the Levites besides who used to be attending to the offerings.

note.gloss: .i. rann do loscud foraltóir et rann aile doairbirt bith doibsom ar ished roerbad friatoschid
note.note: i.e. a part to be burnt on the altar and another part to be eaten by them, for this has been devoted for their sustenance.

note.gloss: .i. amal rombói andlíged sin ifetarlicci atá anísiu ínúiethnissiu
note.note: i.e. as that right has been in (the) Old Law, this is in (the) New Testament.
i.e. honorum which are given for teaching the gospel.
i.e. the glory which will be given to me in heaven.
i.e. by giving me pay for my teaching.

note.gloss: .i. madarlóg pridchasa .i. armetiuth et mothoschith nímbia fochricc dar hési moprecepte
note.note: i.e. if I preach for pay, that is, for my raiment and my sustenance, I shall not have a reward for my teaching.

note.gloss: .i. issumecen precept armetiuth et mothoschid manipridag atbél arócht et gorti
note.note: i.e. it is necessary for me to teach for my raiment and my sustenance: unless I preach I shall perish of cold and hunger.

note.gloss: nisi adnuntiaueris iniquo iniquitatem suam ɫ. bith moircc domsa arócht et gorti manipridach
note.note: it will be woe to me from cold and hunger unless I preach.
i.e. if it is desire that drives me to it: if it is not for pay.

note.gloss: .i. iscennach som madarlóg pridchidir .i. is hed roerpad dom domthoschid
note.note: i.e. it is a bargain if there be preaching for pay, i.e. this has been entrusted to me for my sustenance.
i.e. what is that which gives a reward to me?
i.e. without pay.
i.e. if it be sine sumptu.

note.gloss: .i. airitiu lóge armoprecept arbói són in potestate mea madagnenn
note.note: i.e. to receive pay for my teaching, for that were in potestate mea, if I should do it.
i.e. teaching every one sine uitio.

note.gloss: .i. comtis indbaid iniris ɫ. combetis inindiub fochricce domsa
note.note: i.e. so that they might be rich in faith, or so that they might be in gain of (the) reward to me.

note.gloss: .i. in circumcisione discipuli .i. basa iudide ó écosc
note.note: i.e. I was a Jew in appearance.
i.e. I was not a Jew in customs.
i.e. that I might bring them unto faith.

note.gloss: .i. amal donuic testimni ó altorib innanídol dothaidbsiu indæe infolngithi .i. ueri dei ut dixit uidi áram in qua scriptum erat ignóto deo
note.note: i.e. as he has brought testimonies from the altars of the idols to manifest the hidden God
i.e. through indulgence to them.
i.e. it is for this I have been omnia in omnibus.
in a race.

note.gloss: .i. rethit huili et isóinfer gaibes buáid diib innachomalnad
note.note: i.e. all run, and it is one man of them that gets victory for completing it.

note.gloss: .i. lann segar and issi ede dulchinne inmílti
note.note: i.e. the crown which is sought therein, is the remuneration of the soldier’s service.

note.gloss: non priuabitur quisque suo labore .i. ní ba unus gebas ambuáid huáibsi
note.note: i.e. it will not be (merely) unus of you that will gain the victory.
i.e. that he might be the readier for the victory.
i.e. the crown.
i.e. little is the value for which that labour is performed.

note.gloss: .i. isglé limsa rombia buáid isincertum immurgu ambuáid innammíled talmande hore as ṅ unus accipit palmam
note.note: i.e. it is clear to me that I shall have victory: incertum, however, is the victory of the earthly soldiers, because it is (only) unus accipit palmam.

note.gloss: .i. non ut illi ní amal inní asóircc .i. nifás asaithar dogniusa
note.note: not like him who beats (the air), that is, not void is the labour which I perform.
i.e. through teaching and not accepting pay.

note.gloss: .i. predicationi ɫ. deo et dochomalnad euangelii
note.note: to fulfil the gospel.
i.e. I myself.
i.e. so as not to fulfil that which I preach.

note.gloss: .i. tomad tra et faitgugud anisiu arna imromastar néch
note.note: i.e. a threatening, then, and a cautioning (is) this, lest any one should sin.

note.gloss: .i. an ail innandead ɫ. intuisque iarsinganim ɫ. ishé crist rogenir post
note.note: i.e. their rock behind them: or the water along the sand: or it is Christ who was born post.
i.e. he declares the meaning of it in this.

note.gloss: [in marg.] Ceist cid armbad spiritalis indail. nianse eo quod figurat christum lapidem ángularem isiede indail rúnde asatoróimed asrúaim mór iudforcitil spirdáldi arrodibaid ítith indisrahel spiurdalti innanóib indiththrub in beotho ocascnam tíre tairṅgiri innambéo
note.note: Question, why should the rock be spiritualis? Easy (to answer): eo quod etc. this is the mystical rock out of which has broken the mighty stream of spiritual doctrine, which has quenched the thirst of the spiritual Israel of the saints in the desert of Life, journeying to the Land of Promise of the Living.
i.e. though God has done much of good for them.
i.e. they are not all who have been elect.

note.gloss: .i. docoith dígal forru matis tuicsi ní rígad
note.note: i.e. vengeance fell upon them: if they had been elect it would not have fallen.
i.e. all filii Israhel have not been evil.
i.e. we should pray for nothing that is opposed to our salvation.

note.gloss: .i. fridia et moysi et aarón ut melius nobis seruire in ægipto quam mori in hoc deserto
note.note: i.e. against God and Moses etc.
i.e. for their murmuring.
i.e. who exterminated them in uindicta.
i.e. mirabilia which God has wrought for (the) Children of Israel.
i.e. it is vain to take them from them.

note.gloss: .i. innahí dorigeni día armaccu israhel et na hí dorigénsatsom
note.note: i.e. the things that God has done for the Children of Israel and the things which they have done.
i.e. for our admonition.

note.gloss: [in marg. sup.] isindcinn ... chumme et iniairch ... perfectio detur

note.note: let him beware.
i.e. it is not a suffering that ye could not endure.
profit or increase.

note.gloss: .i. nobsóirfasi dia dinab fochidib bíith dano farcuitsi occa
note.note: i.e. God will liberate you from the sufferings: let then your part be in it (the liberation).

note.gloss: .i. issí tra temptatio homana asrubart túas freccor céil ídol et accobor á túare
note.note: i.e. this, then, is the temptatio humana which he had mentioned above, cultus of idols and desire of their food.

note.gloss: .i. isbées tra donaib dagforcitlidib molad ingni innanétside aracarat anrochlúinetar
note.note: i.e. it is a custom, then, of good teachers to praise the understanding of the hearers that they may love what they hear.
i.e. because it blesses us.
i.e. that bread.
i.e. the idol cannot pollute it.
i.e. that it is anything.
i.e. the idol, then, is not anything.

note.gloss: .i. trithomailt neich adobarar doib eo quod demonís immolat.
note.note: i.e. through consuming aught that is offered to them, eo quod, etc.
i.e. which is filled full of wine on an altar of demons.
i.e. in partaking of Christ’s Body.

note.gloss: .i. ocairbirt biuth neich adoparar do ídlib
note.note: i.e. in partaking of what is offered to idols.
i.e. do we imitate?

note.gloss: .i. coforchongramni manducare idolothyta quae ipse non imperauit
note.note: i.e. that we should order manducare etc.
i.e. in God’s will.

note.gloss: .i. nitattorbi fritoil dée is diliu lemm didiu aní astorbæ oldaas aní as dílmain
note.note: i.e. they are not profitable against God’s will: dearer to me, then, is that which is profitable than that which is lawful.

note.gloss: .i. nacuinged athoil fessin .i. cid tol dó airbert biuth innatúare nach thoimled arna tarta amiris et frithorcuin dondlobur hiressach
note.note: i.e. let him not seek his own desire, that is, though he have a desire to partake of the foods let him not so partake lest he bring unfaith and offence to the weak believer.
i.e. it is free to you.

note.gloss: .i. ni áil dúib áiarfigid arnarala forcubus áiri
note.note: i.e. it is not proper for you to ask it, lest your conscience should suffer because of it(?).

note.gloss: .i. maadced torbe innathect .i. torbe athabarte dochum nirisse
note.note: i.e. if ye should see profit in so going, that is, profit of bringing him to (the) faith.
i.e. because it is an unfaithful one who proclaims it.
i.e. that ye should not partake of it.
i.e. judgment of reprobation.

note.gloss: .i. manud fel inspirut nóib indiumsa ná bith fochunn uaimm fein domæcṅduch .i. per fortitudinem fidei
note.note: i.e. if there is the Holy Spirit within me let me give no cause to speak evil of me.
i.e. for consuming the food.
i.e. this, then, (is) a recapitulation.

note.gloss: .i. isinducbál dodia et isnert nirisse cometecht dondlobur iniriss
note.note: i.e. indulgence to the feeble in faith is glory to God and strength of faith.

note.gloss: .i. cometecht dianécoscaib cenchometecht diambésib mainbet mathi
note.note: i.e. indulgence to their habits without indulgence to their customs, unless they be good.
i.e. what is profit to many, to save them.

note.gloss: arnábad rómár leosom intsamil crist fochetóir
note.note: i.e. lest they might deem it too much to imitate Christ (all) at once.

note.gloss: .i. apridchas diaclaind ɫ. diammuintir ɫ. aliís mulieribus
note.note: i.e. when she preaches to her children, or to her household, uel etc.
i.e. without a veil on her head.

note.gloss: [in marg.] uelato capite .i. moris erat eís uelare capita in orationibus et in predicationibus ɫ. ambith cenchorin ished anuelare asbeirsom
note.note: their being without a (bridal) crown(?), this is the non uelare which he mentions.
i.e. uirum suum, that is, it is a sign of evading the (marriage-)bond.

note.gloss: .i. arisinunn .i. buith nochtchenn .i. amal doberrthe .i. a uiro suo ɫ. ófolt
note.note: i.e. for it is the same, i.e. to be bareheaded, i.e. as though she were shorn, i.e. a uiro suo or from hair.

note.gloss: .i. berrthar non tam imperat tondéri quam detestat ɫ. is cumme dí noberrthe
note.note: i.e. let her be shorn, non tam etc., or it is the same to her as if she had been shorn.

note.gloss: .i. amal ascenn crist uiri iscenn uir mulieris amal dombeir in ben airmitin féith donfiur síc uir christo
note.note: i.e. as Christ is head uiri, uir is head mulieris: as the woman gives due respect to the man, sic uir Christo.

note.gloss: .i. act is ben forchomnucuir dofortacht uiri
note.note: i.e. but it is the woman who was made to help uir.
i.e. because it is propter uirum creata (est).

note.gloss: .i. ciasu airegdu infer arachuit sidi nirubi nechtar de cenalail
note.note: i.e. although for his part the man is nobler neither of them can be without the other.
i.e. bareheaded.
i.e. lex naturae, i.e. nature teaches not.
i.e. it is not seemly.

note.gloss: .i. nifil linn inbéesso .i. tuidecht friaicned et cosnam et imbressan
note.note: i.e we have not this custom, i.e. contravening nature, and quarrelling, and contention.
i.e. it is this which I reprimand at first.

note.gloss: .i. fil ní de asfír ɫ. indrécht uáibsi as debthach ɫ. fidei .i. isindrecht dindhiris adib debthichsi
note.note: i.e. that there is something of it that is true, or it is a section of you that is contentious, uel fidei, i.e. it is as to part of the faith that ye are contentious.

note.gloss: .i. isairchen á buid et ished foirfea scismata rl.
note.note: i.e. it is certain that it is, and it is this which will produce schismata etc.

note.gloss: .i. ní bái lib manducare dominicam cenam sed cenam uestram
note.note: i.e. ye deem it not profitable manducare etc.

note.gloss: barafie dúib darígente cene cenimmormus nachmór
note.note: ye had it in your power to do it, besides, without sin to any great extent.

note.gloss: .i. no indochomainsem ecolsa dagníith. Pelagius: facientes eam triclinium æpularum.
note.note: i.e. or is it to bring contempt on the Church that ye do it?

note.gloss: Gregorius: né putarent corpus domini panem esse commonem indigne eum sumentibus uechimenter comminatur .i. isaidchrochad crist hóre déte dochorp crist indigne
note.note: i.e. it is a re-crucifixion of Christ when one goes to Christ’s Body indigne.

note.gloss: .i. Pelagius: perscrutanda est conscientia sí in nullo nós reprechendit .i. nanglanad triaithirgi ↄnabǽ níi indid ningaba áchocubus
note.note: i.e. let him purify himself through penance, so that there be nothing for which his conscience may reprehend him.
i.e. provided he have no sins.
i.e. weak are all their bodies.

note.gloss: .i. indenmi .i. tesbanat boíll aíriu ɫ. itmoírb inboillsin cia beit innacorp
note.note: i.e. feeble, that is, members are wanting to them, or those limbs are dead though they be in their body.
i.e. they go to premature death, that is, shortness of life.
i.e. to castigate us.
i.e. let every one wait for the other.

note.gloss: .i. arnipalour do intsacarbaicc act ci nip lour nabad in æclesia manducet sed domi
note.note: i.e. for the eucharist will not be enough for him; but though it be not enough, let it not be in ecclesia manducet, sed domi.

note.gloss: .i. madfleteg led magtach dogneid dind æclis
note.note: i.e. if ye make of the church a .......(?) banqueting-house.
i.e. I prefer that ye should know it even now.
i.e. it is clear to you.

note.gloss: .i. eo quod eratis similes simulacrorum .i. arnitucsidsi issuidiu etargne crist .i. arindfessid
note.note: i.e. for at this (time) ye did not understand the knowledge of Christ, i.e. that ye may know it.

note.gloss: .i. primitus dis .i. nípa híspirut dée cíatbera
note.note: i.e. it will not be in the spirit of God although he say it.

note.gloss: .i. itíli immurgu dona gratiae spiritus sancti ciasu óende inspirut
note.note: i.e. many, however, are dona etc. though the Spirit is single.

note.gloss: [in marg.] trianman dobeirsom híc spiritui .i. spiritus et dominus et deus ostenditur híc nách neich ingním sed spiritus
note.note: three names he gives híc Spiritui, etc. Ostenditur híc that the work belongs to no one sed Spiritus.

note.gloss: .i. foilsigthi inspirut andsom arrath dobeir do
note.note: i.e. the Spirit manifests in him the grace which it gives him.
i.e. that is, one Spirit distributes it.

note.gloss: Pelagius: ut curat egrótos ut sunt medici ɫ. dénom ferto
note.note: working a miracle (of healing).

note.gloss: .i. tintuúth bélri innaláil ut hieronimus et LXX. ɫ. rúna dothabairt á óensonaib et precept essib iarum ut mós est predicatoribus
note.note: i.e. translation of (one) language into another like Jerome and the Septuagint, or to bring hidden meanings out of single words, and then to preach from them, ut etc.

note.gloss: .i. spiritus doadbadar sunt atánili dána inspirto et asnóindæ inspirut
note.note: here is shewn that the Spirit’s gifts are many and that the Spirit is single.

note.gloss: cosmulius tra anísiu lessom .i. amal fongní cach ball dialailiu isinchorp arafogna talland cáich uanni dialailiu arammi óinchórp hí crist
note.note: this, then, is a simile of his, that is: as every member serves the other in the body, that the talent of every one of us should serve the other, for we are one body in Christ.
those members, though they be many, are (one) body.
i.e. it is one body with Christ.
i.e. we have been massed into one body by baptism.

note.gloss: .i. ataat uili isinchorpsin .i. iudei et genti[les]
note.note: i.e. all are in that body.
i.e. we have drunk a great draught of the grace of the Holy Spirit.

note.gloss: .i. nicorp intóinbáll 19 .i. arit boill immefolṅget corp
note.note: i.e. the one member is not a body.

note.gloss: .i. issochrudiu láam oldósa olcoss nidichorp atóosa hóre nimthalaám
note.note: i.e. ‘Hand is comelier than I,’ says Foot. ‘I am not of the body because I am not Hand.’

note.gloss: .i. ní nád ṁ bed arse dichorp act atá de
note.note: i.e. not that it is not therefore of the body, but it is of it.

note.gloss: [in marg.] Mad inæclis tra inchoss ishé óis achtáil et indlaám ishé óis achtáil asmáa alailiu
note.note: if, then, it be in the Church, the foot is the practical folk, and the hand is the practical folk who are more than the others.
i.e. the contemplative folk.
i.e. the field which the eye has taken in is more delightful than I am.

note.gloss: .i. aráchuit sidi is de corpore dissi
note.note: i.e. as regards it: it is de corpore.
that, too, will be body.
i.e. posuit verily membrum.

note.gloss: .i. isamlid dorígeni dia corp duini ó ilballaib
note.note: i.e. it is thus that God hath made man’s body of many members.
i.e. verily He hath established one body of many members.
i.e. I need you not, O feet!

note.gloss: .i. níhed améit nádricc less cachball aláili sed multo rl.
note.note: i.e. not only cannot any member dispense with the other, sed multo, etc.

note.gloss: .i. ata lobru amal rongab cride et óa et inmedóncha áili ɫ. uirilia et feminina
note.note: i.e. which are weaker, such as the heart and liver and other internal organs.

note.gloss: .i. andíten issairiu doib fognam donaballaib ailib doib oldaas cidafognam féisne cianubed leu
note.note: i.e. of protecting them: it is nobler for them to serve the other members than even to serve themselves, though it should be in their power.

note.gloss: .i. tri fognam innamball naile doib .i. dothinóol ǽtig impu et biith doib
note.note: i.e. through the service of the other members to them, that is, in gathering raiment round them and food for them.
i.e. face and hands and feet.

note.gloss: .i. honestatis .i. andudæsta airisom .i. líi et sonirte immefolṅgi incorp uile andsom ón
note.note: i.e. what is lacking unto it, i.e. colour and firmness, that makes up the whole body therein.

note.gloss: .i. ↄderna cechball anastoisc dialailiu hore isin oínchorp ataat badmaith anóintu
note.note: i.e. so that each member may do what the other desires: because they are in one body let their unity be good.
i.e. as they exist.

note.gloss: .i. hore is oín chorp cobrad cachball alaile
note.note: i.e. because it is one body let each member help the other.
i.e. though ye do not deem that union close.

note.gloss: .i. isgalar leu uili mabed galar issindoínbull
note.note: i.e. they all deem themselves sick if sickness should be in the one member.

note.gloss: .i. mad slaán in ball iar nagalar isdidnad donaib ballaib ailib
note.note: i.e. if the member be whole after its sickness it is a consolation to the other members.

note.gloss: .i. issuaichnid tra cid diatuiced incosmuilius cosse .i. amal file óentid eterbaullu coirp duini conroib oíntu etrunni dano hore ammicorp crist et ammiboill coirp crist
note.note: i.e. it is apparent, then, for what the similitude has been put hitherto, to wit, as there is unity among the members of a human being’s body, that there be union among us also, because we are Christ’s body and we are members of Christ’s body.

note.gloss: .i. ithé rogabsat airegas quia uiderunt apostoli quae profetae profetauerunt
note.note: i.e. it is they (the apostles) that have received precedence quia etc.

note.gloss: .i. óis anamchairtessa in praesenti tantum docentes
note.note: i.e. the spiritual directors in praesenti etc.

note.gloss: .i. indíi gnite gnímu sainemli ɫ. denum ferte
note.note: i.e. they that do excellent deeds, or working miracles.

note.gloss: .i. fortactidi .i. in doctrína et oratióne ɫ. in elimoisinis
note.note: i.e. helpers.
vice-abbots.

note.gloss: .i. abnegatiue .i. nítat apstil huili luct inna æcolsa
note.note: i.e. the church-folk are not all apostles.
i.e. all are not teachers.
i.e. all do not work miracles.
i.e. all have not the grace of working miracles.
i.e. all do not speak with many tongues.

note.gloss: .i. nitatsoír huili oc tintuúth abélru innalaill ɫ. ocsaigid forsunu ɫ. octabairt ruún essib
note.note: i.e. all are not skilled in translating from one language into another, or in disputing as to words, or in bringing hidden meanings out of them.

note.gloss: .i. quam labrath ó ilbélrib, et adhuc excellentiorem uiam uobís demonstro
note.note: i.e. than speaking in many languages.
i.e. this is the demonstrabo.
i.e. a suitable love for God.
i.e. brass that soundeth, i.e. even devotion without charity.
i.e. which shines or sounds.
i.e. grace of preaching.
i.e. of what has been done and will be done.
i.e. of working miracles.
i.e. nothing of that profits me.

note.gloss: tairchella híc tra huili dánu inspirito et nitorban na áe manihǽ desercc
note.note: he collects(?) híc, then, all the gifts of the Spirit, and none of them profiteth unless there be charity.

note.gloss: .i. in mortem ardagní sochuide báas aracharit
note.note: i.e. in mortem, for many a one dies for his friend.
nearer and nearer, until he (Paul) has come to himself.
i.e. better is charity than all things are.

note.gloss: [in marg.] peram .i. forcrith .i. in cibis et uestimentis
note.note: i.e. wrongly(?).
i.e. save God’s love tantum.

note.gloss: .i. in futuro .i. nirecar less legind and
note.note: i.e. study is not needed there.
i.e. we shall not speak, that is, his caritas, however, will accompany him beyond.
i.e. it is little we know in God’s mysteries.

note.gloss: .i. isbecc pridchimmeni dirúnaib dǽe ar nisfitemmar
note.note: i.e. it is little we preach of God’s mysteries, for we know them not.

note.gloss: .i. buíth dunni issintodochidiu .i. uita futura ɫ. plena scientia
note.note: i.e. that we should be in the future.
i.e. I used to feel.

note.gloss: .i. ó domanicc foirbthetu ní denim gnímu macthi act rísam nem bimmi æcni et bimmi foirbthi uili
note.note: i.e. since perfection has come to me, I do no childish deeds; if only we get to heaven we shall be wise, and we shall all be perfect.
i.e. he has here a similitude of an eye.

note.gloss: .i. iscumme adciamni narúna diadi et adcíi nech ní triscáath céin ṁbimme in corpore
note.note: i.e. so long as we are in corpore, we see the divine mysteries just as one sees something through a mirror.
i.e. for what is seen through darkness is not clear, and is not quite certain.

note.gloss: .i. isrándindeacht adgénsa ɫ. is ran indiumsa adgeuín indeacht .i. anima tantum adidgeúin
note.note: i.e. it is (only) a part of the Godhead which I know, or it is a part in me that knows the Godhead, that is, anima tantum has this knowledge.

note.gloss: .i. bid ex toto són immurgu nipa ex parte
note.note: i.e. that, however, will be ex toto: it will not be ex parte.
i.e. this is their number.
i.e. even in the present world.

note.gloss: .i. dona caritatis .i. atréde túas spes fides caritas
note.note: i.e. the three things above, spes, fides etc.
(that) ye may teach.
i.e. he who speaks many languages.
i.e. for they understand it not.
i.e. he understands it.

note.gloss: .i. rocluinethar cách infogur et níↄfitir cid asbeir
note.note: i.e. every one hears the sound and knows not what he says.
i.e. who preaches.
i.e. that is profit.
i.e. it is his own profit only.

note.gloss: .i. tuicci feissin ɫ. doáircci molad do
note.note: i.e. he himself understands, or it produces praise for him.
i.e. who preaches.
i.e. that is (the) profit of many.

note.gloss: .i. niarformut fribsi asbiursa inso arropad maith limsa labrad ilbelre dúibsi
note.note: i.e. I say this not because of envy towards you, for I should like you to speak many tongues.
i.e. that, however, I should prefer.

note.gloss: .i. isferr limsa didiu aní tairci inbríg móir sin duibsi
note.note: i.e. I prefer, then, that which produces that great privilege to you.

note.gloss: [in marg.] Acht nammáa issamlid istorbe són co etercerta anasbera et conrucca inætarcne cáich
note.note: only thus that is profitable, provided he interpret what he says and bring (it) into every one’s understanding.
i.e. so that many may believe through him.
i.e. through many languages.

note.gloss: .i. dobéer desemmrecht dúib indorsa frissacomricfea farnaire
note.note: i.e. I will now give you an example which your attention will attain to.
i.e. what is my profit to you if I speak thus?
i.e. so that it may be manifest to every one.
i.e. so that every one may know.

note.gloss: [in marg.] Aut profetia .i. hiprecept .i. todiusgud neích dochretim condip irlam do baithius
note.note: i.e. in preaching, that is, rousing any one to believe so that he may be ready for baptism.
i.e. teaching any one after his baptism.
i.e. pipe.
i.e. harp.

note.gloss: .i. manibée dechur isint senmuim nítucatar innarríara
note.note: i.e. unless there be a difference in the sound, the notes are not understood.
i.e. what is played on the pipe or harp.
or what is harped.

note.gloss: [in marg.] cosmulius aile lessom inso .i. cosmulius tuib arataat ilsenman dosuidiu et issain cach næ .i. issain fricath sain friscor ɫ. fri imthect ɫ. frisuan ɫ. comairli mani dechrigedar (i)nfer nodseinn .i. mad óinríar dogné nítucthar cid frissasennar isamlid dano maní dechrigther et manitintither (am)bélre nechtrann nithucci incách rod chluinethar

note.note: i.e. like to you are these two things.
i.e. unless ye translate.

note.gloss: .i. ináer .i. accusatiuus grecus .i. bid essarcon aiéir dúib arnitucfa nech anasberith
note.note: i.e. into air, i.e. it will be a beating of the air by you, for no one will understand what ye will say.

note.gloss: .i. ciniglé lib ataat ilchenéle bérli isinbiuthso
note.note: i.e. is it not clear to you that there are in this world many kinds of language?

note.gloss: .i. ni ↄfil tra belre issin cenfogur .i. cetorbe dúibsi didiu infogur sin mani fessid inni bess fonfogursin
note.note: i.e. there is not, then, a language in this world without sound, that is, what profit to you then (is) this sound unless ye know the sense which is under that sound?

note.gloss: .i. arnitucci ambéelre asbiur ishe asbéra iarum barbár inso
note.note: i.e. for he understands not the language I speak. It is he, then, that will say: ‘this is a barbarian.’

note.gloss: .i. hóre isamne atáa tra .i. isferr precept oldaas labrad ilbéelre bad hed dogneithsi
note.note: i.e. since then it is thus, i.e. better is preaching than speaking many languages, be it this that ye do.
i.e. let it be thus that ye speak well with an interpretation.

note.gloss: .i. sulbairiged ɫ. oret deum ut interpretetur .i. ut possit (inte)llegi sensus.
note.note: i.e. let him speak well.
i.e. though I speak well.

note.gloss: .i. níthucci momenme immurgu .i. quia non intellego quod loquor
note.note: i.e. my mind, however, understands it not.

note.gloss: .i. cid asmaith disunt tra nianse sulbirigfer spiritu et mente .i. tucfa momenme anasbérat mo beiúil
note.note: i.e. what then is good therefrom? Easy (to answer); I will speak well spiritu et mente, i.e. my mind will understand what my lips will utter.

note.gloss: .i. cid asbere siu ond fógur tantum
note.note: i.e. what thou shalt say with the sound tantum.
i.e. who shall fill?

note.gloss: .i. cóor ɫ. locc rélto et foilsichtho ar nitorbe do maniréltar do
note.note: i.e. place, or locality of explaining and manifesting; for it is no profit to him unless it is explained to him.
i.e. to the simpleton or to the ignorant one.
i.e. on the abundance of the teaching which thou utterest.

note.gloss: .i. nifiastar som cia airm indid immaircide do epert amén
note.note: i.e. he will not know at what place in it it is fitting for him to say amen.
i.e. it is not easy for him to say amen in that wise.

note.gloss: .i. doadbadar immurgu trisincainaisṅdíis file rath dée latso act nitorbe donach ailiu
note.note: i.e. it is, however, shewn by the fair statement that God’s grace is in thee; but it is no profit to any one else.

note.gloss: .i. arna tomontis dano nambadrath spirito labrad ilbéelre asbeirsom anísiu
note.note: i.e. he says this lest they should suppose then that speaking many tongues is not a grace of the Spirit.
i.e. I, indeed, am fit to interpret it.

note.gloss: .i. insians ondid accobor limsa ícc cáich
note.note: i.e. the understanding from which I desire to save every one.

note.gloss: .i. cipcruth tra olse irmith sed in æclesia rl.
note.note: i.e. ‘howsoever, then, it is,’ says he, ‘ .... ’

note.gloss: .i. foirbthe aranfoirbthiu inso .i. deich míli briathar ar labrad ilbélre et nistuccin ut predicarem ea
note.note: i.e. ‘perfect for imperfect’ (is) this, that is, ‘ten thousand words’ for ‘speaking many tongues’; and I should not understand them ut praedicarem ea.

note.gloss: .i. do óis anfoirbthiu tra asrobrad insin nabad anfoirbthisi dano arnáp immaircide dúib
note.note: i.e. to imperfect folk that, now, has been said. Be ye not imperfect, then, lest it be appropriate to you.
i.e. it (the Jewish people) will know every language when it shall be carried into captivity.

note.gloss: .i. ciarud chualatar ilbélre et cenuslabratar nipat ferr de isfollus didiu nanmáar bríg labrad ilbélre
note.note: i.e. though they have heard many languages, and though they speak them, they will not be the better for it. It is manifest, then, that speaking many languages is not of great value.

note.gloss: .i. ished torbe nammáa tra aratobarr labrad ilbelre conroadamrigther dia triit et combat irlamude indancreitmich dochretim
note.note: i.e. this, then, is the only profit for which speaking many tongues is given, that God may be glorified thereby and that unbelievers may be the readier to believe.
i.e. preceptors.
i.e. teaching, however, it is to the faithful folk.
i.e. also to forbid greed.
i.e. without profitableness of teaching.
i.e. simpletons or unfaithful men.
or the simpletons.
i.e. this is what they will say: ‘these men are mad.’
i.e. if they preach.
i.e. judgment is passed upon him.

note.gloss: .i. trissinprecept bésti ituisemar bestatu cáich et ní fristait inbéstatid nisin .i. gním et briathar et imbrádud
note.note: i.e. through the moral teaching in which every one’s morality is generated; and what opposes(?) that morality, to wit, deed and word and cogitation.
i.e. (that) every one of these men is a prophet.

note.gloss: .i. cid asdénti frisin tra nianse gaibed cách ásalmu et forcanad et foilsiged ciped techtas nech bad ad edificationem
note.note: i.e. what then is to be done with reference to that? Easy (to answer): let every one sing his psalms, and teach and set forth: whatever it is that any one has, let it be ad aedificationem.

note.gloss: Pelagius: intellectum salmi .i. tuicci angaibes insalm
note.note: i.e. he understands what the psalm says.
i.e. after baptism.
i.e. manifestation of mysteries.
i.e. speaking many languages, with their translation into another language.
i.e. out of a language into a language.

note.gloss: .i. sechiphé dán tra doberthar doneuch bad fricumtach necolso immabera .i. cumtach sochuide inhiris
note.note: i.e. whatever, then, be the gift that shall be bestowed on any one, let it be for the edification of the Church that he employs it, even edification of a multitude in faith.

note.gloss: .i. mabeith nech and tra labrathar ilbélre nabad lia diis nothriur dano
note.note: i.e. if there be any one, then, who speaks many languages, let it not be more than two or three persons then,

note.gloss: .i. loquantur .i. act badchách darési áréli .i. nabad immalle labritir
note.note: i.e. but let it be each one after the other, that is, let them not speak at the same time.

note.gloss: .i. badóinfeir nodpridcha arisdochruth comirsire nadesse ɫ. intríir etarcertar oinfer inchrud sin
note.note: i.e. let it be one man who preaches it, for unseemly is the barking(?) of two or three at the same time. One man is interpreted in that manner.
i.e. for it will not understand it.
i.e. he himself understands it tantum.

note.gloss: .i. islour dapreceptóir inæclis nothíi descipuil olchene et foglimthidi cách darhési álaili
note.note: i.e. enough are two teachers in a church or three: disciples besides and students, each after the other.

note.gloss: [in marg.] .i. conicfidsi bede preceptori uili trisanimthanadsa diacoitsea cách frialaile
note.note: i.e. ye will all be able to be teachers through this alternation if each listen to the other.

note.gloss: .i. éitset frisinprecept et berat brith fuiri quia mos est apud illos freisṅdis predicatorum
note.note: i.e. let them listen to the teaching and pass judgment upon it, quia mos est apud illos confutation praedicatorum.

note.gloss: .i. mabeidní dirúnaib dothéi armenmuin indfir bíis innasuidiu et adreig
note.note: i.e. if aught of the mysteries should come into the mind of the man who is sitting, and he rises.

note.gloss: achele .i. intí ropo magister prius combidescipul post
note.note: his fellow, i.e. he that was master prius, so that he becomes disciple post.

note.gloss: [in marg.] Frecre lessom inso mentibus illorum ma asberad nech intain asṁbeirsom potestis enim per singulos rl. .i. bid (prec)eptóir cách and (ol)isamein conicfedsi profetare mad per singulos Ceist tra et mulieres cid dogénat sidi hipridchabat nathó olpol taceant rl.
note.note: This an answer of his mentibus illorum, if, when he says potestis etc., i.e., ‘every one will be a teacher there. For it is thus that ye will be able prophetare, if it be per singulos,’ any one should say: ‘Question, then, et mulieres? what will these do? will they preach?’ ‘No,’ says Paul, ‘taceant’ etc.
i.e. taceant indeed, that is, all who are listening.
i.e. all who preach.

note.gloss: .i. bertit alaili tra combad spirut nóib robói in profetís ueteris combadhé bad foammamigthe profetís noui .i. apostolis, quod non uerum air ní díib attáa briathar less híc sed de paedicatoribus
note.note: i.e. some take it that it was the Holy Spirit who was in prophetis Veteris (Testamenti), who was subjected prophetis Novi (Testamenti), i.e. apostolis; quod non uerum, for it is not of them (the prophets of the O.T.) that he (Paul) speaks hic, sed de praedicatoribus.
i.e. attention to another is due from every one.
i.e. that He is a God of peace and is of concord.

note.gloss: .i. sí sint uiri in presentia arisinsæ inball dothinchosc neich asberad cenn
note.note: for it is impossible that the member should correct what the head might utter.

note.gloss: .i. issuaícnid tra nipo accobor lassinfeir nopridchad suide et acheile dothuidect darahési amæ ǽm nípo uáib act ba o apsatalib
note.note: i.e. it is obvious, then, that the man who used to preach had no desire to sit down, and his fellow to come in his place. Verily, indeed, it was not from you, but from (the) apostles.

note.gloss: [in marg.] .i. indúib nammá ropridchad amae ni dúib sed omnibus gentibus. Án a uobís .i. nitacair denum domuin dind soscélu
note.note: i.e. is it to you only that there has been preaching? Verily not to you (alone), sed omnibus gentibus. It is not meet to make (aught) profound of the Gospel.

note.gloss: .i. bíith amenme frisso bad samlid pridchaid
note.note: i.e. let his mind be to this: let him preach thus.

note.gloss: .i. act cuit ascribint domsa it domini som immurgu
note.note: i.e. except in their having been written by me; they are the Lord’s, however.
i.e. a Deo in bestowal of grace.
i.e. but let it be as I say it.
i.e. provided it be with interpretation of those languages.
i.e. (to forbid) you yourselves or any one else.

note.gloss: [in marg.] Farcongair som tra sunt indsamuil precepte et labrad ilbélre act ropochotorbu æcolsa
note.note: Here, then, he orders (them) to imitate (his) preaching and to speak many languages, provided it be with profit to the Church.
i.e. let every act be in its proper order.

note.gloss: .i. badféal et badfedte dogneid cachréit cid precept cid labrad ilbélre bed amal asinbiursa dogneither et is béim foris inso forsnadlígetha remeperthi ɫ. istitul indligid archiunn
note.note: i.e. let it be faithfully and let it be honorably that ye do everything. Whether it be preaching, whether it be speaking many languages, let it be done as I say it. And this is a recapitulation of the aforesaid dicta. Or it is the title of the dictum ahead.
i.e. ye have indeed received my teaching.
i.e. that is a praise to them.
i.e. as hath been preached to you, let it he thus that ye fulfil it.

note.gloss: .i. bacoir cenachomalnithe ropridchad mór namri dúib
note.note: i.e. it were fitting that ye should fulfil it: much of marvel has been preached unto you.
i.e. except the belief which ye have believed is vain.

note.gloss: .i. aní itáa cuntubart libsi .i. esséirge ished rorélus dúib recachréit
note.note: i.e. that as to which there is doubt among you, to wit, resurrection, this is what I have set forth to you before everything.

note.gloss: .i. amal donairchet hífáithib et rofiugrad irrect et amal asṅindedar issoscélu
note.note: i.e. as hath been foretold in the Prophets and hath been figured in the Law, and as is declared in the Gospel.
of Zion.

note.gloss: [in summo marg.] ... (doadb)adar intaidbsiu hi siu tra do(naib) coic cetaib ...... robói isinchaithir isindaimsirsin
note.note: this appearance, then, is manifested to the five hundred ...... that was in the city at that time.

note.gloss: .i. oillu oldate cóiccét fer dodemnigud tra resurrectionis
note.note: i.e. more than five hundred men; for certifying resurrectionis then.

note.gloss: .i. in uita .i. mad aill duib cid accaldam neich diib darigente
note.note: i.e. if ye desired even to converse with any of them, ye could do it.
i.e. youngest.

note.gloss: .i. arismiad mór indapstalacht .i. buid fortectairecht hó ísu
note.note: i.e. for a great honour is the apostleship, even to be on an embassy from Jesus.

note.gloss: .i. israd dée immumforling conda apstal liussa
note.note: i.e. God’s grace has caused me to be an apostle ....

note.gloss: .i. non sine operibus .i. nírbu faás foruigéni
note.note: i.e. not void has been his service,
though he was minimus and though he was abortiuus.

note.gloss: .i. isoéntu forcitil linn hóre isóenrad fíl linn
note.note: i.e. it is unity of teaching to us because it is one grace that we have.
i.e. as we have preached it, ye have believed it.

note.gloss: .i. isaithiss doibsom cid anísiu .i. cenprecept dondais anfiss
note.note: i.e. even this is a disgrace to them, that is, not to preach to the ignorant folk.

note.gloss: .i. masuglé lib tra inprecept ropridchussa .i. asréracht crist hómarbaib cid dialeícid cundubairt fordrecht uáib de resurrectione hominum
note.note: i.e. if, then, the doctrine which I have preached is clear to you, to wit, that Christ hath arisen from the dead, why do ye leave doubt on a section of you de resurrectione hominum?

note.gloss: .i. isgnáth tra inso dond óis glicc dolleicet forru indáil et fobenat iarum innadeud hórogaibther cíall forriuth combi remib rethith iarum
note.note: i.e. this, then, is usual for the cunning folk, (that) they let the crowd pass them and then steal up(?) after it when they are intent on running, so that afterwards he runs before them.

note.gloss: .i. isuabar et isfass dúnni apridchimme manidfír ut dicunt illi
note.note: i.e. vanity and void for us is what we preach unless it is true ut etc.
i.e. it is false testimony which we give of God in that case.
i.e. that witness is against Godhead.

note.gloss: .i. límmi fordia ní nád deirgéni inchruthsin .i. todiusgud crist
note.note: i.e. we impute to God a thing which He has not done in that wise, to wit, the raising of Christ.

note.gloss: .i. isairi ǽm liimse forrusom díltud eisséirgi crist hóre disluindet resurrectionem mortuorum
note.note: i.e. therefore do I accuse them of denying Christ’s resurrection, because they deny resurrectionem mortuorum.

note.gloss: .i. issuáichnid manidchretid esséirge crist et mortuorum nibnóibfea for nires inchruthsin et níbscara fribarpecthu
note.note: i.e. it is manifest (that) unless ye believe the resurrection of Christ et mortuorum, your faith will not sanctify you in that wise, and doth not sever you from your sins.
i.e. it is perishing to them unless they have life eternal.

note.gloss: .i. massu bethu crist nammá cretmeni issiu ɫ. massu armbethuni siu nammá
note.note: i.e. if it is Christ’s life only that we believe here, or if it is our life here only.
i.e. beyond every one.

note.gloss: .i. ished ón immurgu as fír et isfír dano esséirge omnium post sé
note.note: i.e. it is that, however, which is true, and true, moreover, is resurrection omnium post sé.
